sen.j: 高城（たかじょう）は宮崎県（旧日向国）にあった城で同名の城が3つ存在する。
sen.e: Taka-jo Castles existed in Miyazaki Prefecture (former Hyuga Province), and there were three castles that had the same name.
Taka-jo Castles existed in Miyazaki Prefecture (former Hyuga Province); there were three castles that had this name.
Taka-jo Castles existed in Miyazaki Prefecture (former Hyuga Province); there were three castles that had this name.

sen.j: また、三重県（旧伊勢国）にも同名の城があり、下記のいずれかを指す。
sen.e: In addition, Mie Prefecture (former Ise Province) had another castle of the same name; thus, Taka-jo Castle indicates one of the following castles.
In addition, Mie Prefecture (former Ise Province) had another castle of the same name; thus, Taka-jo Castle indicates one of the following castles.
In addition, Mie Prefecture (former Ise Province) had another castle of the same name; thus, Taka-jo Castle indicates one of the following castles.

sen.j: 新納院（現・宮崎県児湯郡木城町）にあった高城。
sen.e: Taka-jo Castle that existed in Niiroin (present-day Kijo-cho, Koyu-gun, Miyazaki Prefecture).
Taka-jo Castle that existed in Niiroin (present-day Kijo-cho, Koyu-gun, Miyazaki Prefecture).
Taka-jo Castle that existed in Niiroin (present-day Kijo-cho, Koyu-gun, Miyazaki Prefecture).

sen.j: 高城 (新納院) を参照。
sen.e: Refer to Taka-jo Castle (Niiroin).

sen.j: 三俣院（現・宮崎県都城市高城町）にあった高城。
sen.e: Taka-jo Castle that existed in Mimatain (present-day Takajo-cho, Miyakonojo City, Miyazaki Prefecture).
Taka-jo Castle that existed in Mimatain (present-day Takajo-cho, Miyakonojo City, Miyazaki Prefecture).
Taka-jo Castle that existed in Mimatain (present-day Takajo-cho, Miyakonojo City, Miyazaki Prefecture).

sen.j: 高城 (三俣院) を参照。
sen.e: Refer to Taka-jo Castle (Mimatain).
Refer to Taka-jo Castle (Mimatain).

sen.j: 穆佐院（現・宮崎県宮崎市高岡町 (宮崎県)）にあった高城。
sen.e: Taka-jo Castle that existed in Mukasain (present-day Takaoka-cho, Miyazaki City, Miyazaki Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 「(宮崎県)」が重複していましたので省きました。（ウェブ上でも削除されていました。）
sen.e: Taka-jo Castle that existed in Mukasain (present-day Takaoka-cho, Miyazaki City, Miyazaki Prefecture).
Taka-jo Castle that existed in Mukasain (present-day Takaoka-cho, Miyazaki City, Miyazaki Prefecture).

sen.j: 高城 (穆佐院) を参照。
sen.e: Refer to Taka-jo Castle (Mukasain).

Refer to Taka-jo Castle (Mukasain).

sen.j: 伊勢（現・三重県松阪市）にあった高城。
sen.e: Taka-jo Castle that existed in Ise (present-day Matsusaka City, Mie Prefecture).
Taka-jo Castle that existed in Ise (present-day Matsusaka City, Mie Prefecture).

sen.j: 高城 (伊勢国) を参照。
sen.e: Refer to Taka-jo Castle (Ise Province).
Refer to Taka-jo Castle (Ise Province).

sen.j: 高城（たかしろ）は肥前国高来郡にあった城。
sen.e: Takashiro castle, which uses the same characters as Taka-jo Castle in Japanese, is a castle that existed in Takaku District, Hizen Province.
sen.cmt: 漢字について補足説明を加えました。（"which uses the same characters as Taka-jo Castle in Japanese"）
sen.e: Takashiro castle, which in Japanese is written with the same characters as Taka-jo Castle, is a castle that existed in Takaku District, Hizen Province.
Takashiro castle, which in Japanese is written with the same characters as Taka-jo Castle, is a castle that existed in Takaku District, Hizen Province.

sen.j: 中世の伊佐早荘（現諫早市にほぼ相当）を領した西郷信尚が築城し、西郷氏の居城であった。
sen.e: It was built and resided in by Nobunao SAIGO, who ruled Isahaya no sho Estate (mostly corresponding to present-day Isahaya City) in the medieval period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It was built by and the home of Nobunao SAIGO, who ruled Isahaya no sho Estate (mostly corresponding to present-day Isahaya City) in the medieval period.
It was built by and the home of Nobunao SAIGO, who ruled Isahaya no sho Estate (mostly corresponding to present-day Isahaya City) in the medieval period.

sen.j: だが、豊臣秀吉の九州の役に伴い龍造寺家晴に奪われ、近世においては子孫の諫早家の居城となった。
sen.e: The castle, however, was taken by Ieharu RYUZOJI as a result of the Battle of Kyushu waged by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and in the early-modern times, it became a residential castle of the Isahaya family, offspring of Ieharu RYUZOJI.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The castle, however, was taken by Ieharu RYUZOJI as a result of the Battle of Kyushu waged by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and in early-modern times, it became a residential castle of the Isahaya family, the offspring of Ieharu RYUZOJI.

The castle, however, was taken by Ieharu RYUZOJI as a result of the Battle of Kyushu waged by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and in early-modern times, it became a residential castle of the Isahaya family, the offspring of Ieharu RYUZOJI.
